title.text: A UNIFICATION-BASED PARSER FOR RELATIONAL GRAMMAR

entities.text: A UNIFICATION-BASED PARSER FOR RELATIONAL GRAMMAR

abstractContent.text: We present an implemented unification-based parser for relational grammars developed within the stratified feature grammar (SFG) framework , which generalizes Kasper-Rounds logic to handle relational grammar analyses.
We first introduce the key aspects of SFG and a lexicalized, graph-based variant of the framework suitable for implementing relational grammars.
We then describe a head-driven chart parser for lexicalized SFG.
The basic parsing operation is essentially ordinary feature-structure unification augmented with an operation of label unification to build the stratified features characteristic of SFG.

introductionContent.text: Although the impact of relational grammar (RG) on theoretical linguistics has been substantial, it has never previously been put in a form suitable for computational use.
RG's multiple syntactic strata would seem to preclude its use in the kind of monotonic, unification-based parsing system many now consider standard (,).

However, recent work by Johnson and Moss on a Kasper-Rounds (KR) style logic-based formalism for RG, called Stratified Feature Grammar (S FG), has demonstrated that even RG's multiple strata are amenable to a feature-structure treatment.
Based on this work, we have developed a unification-based, chart parser fora lexical version of SFG suitable for building computational relational grammars.
A lexicalized SFG is simply a collection of stratified feature graphs (Sgraphs), each of which is anchored to a lexical item, analogous to lexicalized TAGs.

The basic parsing operation of the system is S-graph unification (S-unification): This is essentially ordinary feature-structure unification augmented with an operation of label unification to build the stratified features characteristic of SFG.
